conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light; size and position depend on light source position.
Shadows A, B, C, and D are currently cast on the ground by the objects above them.
Moving the light source backward changes the angle of light rays, affecting shadow position and size.
Shadows will shift closer to the objects as the light source moves backward.
Shadows will become smaller because the light source is farther away, causing light rays to converge more directly.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will shift closer to the objects and become smaller.
